@rileyphughes @niels_klomp @TimoGlastra @IdentityWoman I kinda mean both, though for different reasons. The protocol defs have a growing home at the DIDComm UG at the DIF. The codebases will continue, with possible adjustments as community chooses.

@TimoGlastra @rileyphughes DIDComm is standardized inside DIF. 
That process seems to have gone well. 
People are generally happy with that spec. 
Implementations outside of the Aries/Indy.

@IdentityWoman @rileyphughes I think one of the main thing I'm having issues with is that Aries/Indy/AnonCreds/DIDComm are being conflated and therefore the issues of one of them, are issues of all of them.

But that's probably because the early implementations were tightly coupled

@IdentityWoman @rileyphughes I'm trying to change my opinion. What do you think we need to do to fix Aries/AnonCreds/Indy/DIDComm?

As I see it, people like DIDComm, are not a fan of the weak standardization process in Aries and hate AnonCreds & Indy.  Does that sum it up?

First Public Working Draft: Verifiable Credentials JSON Schema Specification 2023 
This specifies the models used for Verifiable Credentials, Verifiable Presentations, and explains the relationships between three parties: issuers, holders, and verifiers. 
https://t.co/5PmwUr8Tbs

#DigiYatra built on #W3C standards using Self Sovereign Identity (SSI), Verifiable Credentials (VC), Decentralized Identifiers (#DIDs) & uses a Distributed Ledger for decentralised layer of trust b/w the various participants of the ecosystem.
https://t.co/BIXWWQvNjq

@simulxxx @SimpleXChat There is a very narrow window where we can learn from AtProtocol choices for a personal data server, and build similar architecture while they are busy with moderation hell.

If missed, did:plc, the worst did ever, will become the norm of data stores.
